title: Goldman Sachs cracks open Owens-Illinois bottles sale
text:
Investment bank Goldman Sachs has kicked off a sale for the country's biggest maker of beer and wine bottles on behalf of American company Owens-Illinois.

Goldman Sachs' bankers sent a nine-point pitch to potential buyers over the weekend and revealed the up-for-sale business recorded $750 million a year revenue and $140 million in earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation.

Potential buyers were told Owens-Illinois' local business was the largest manufacturer of glass bottles and containers in Australia and New Zealand, supplying 850,000 tonnes of glass products a year.

Owens-Illinois' local arm makes half of its revenue from the manufacture and sale of beer bottles. Jim Rice

Half of its revenue comes from beer bottles, while 30 per cent is tied to wine and there is another 10 per cent in non-alcoholic beverages.

Its customers include beermaker Kirin and its Australian arm Lion, Japanese rival Asahi, Heineken, Independent Wine Group, Treasury Wine Estates and ginger beer maker Bundaberg, according to a sale flyer obtained by Street Talk.
description: Goldman Sachs has begun a sale of Australia's biggest beer and wine bottle maker on behalf of Owens-Illinois.
